text_clean: Appreciate it! Here's how it works: You add recipients with their email, phone number, or both. Then you choose how each recipient gets notified when the time comes - email, SMS, or both. You set your check-in schedule (weekly, monthly, whatever works). If you fail to check in the check in, and grace period you set, the system automatically delivers everything to the right people based on what you assigned to them. Recipients don't need to do anything until the moment it matters. But if you want to bring family on board now, there's a Family plan where multiple people can organize together. Let me know how it goes - early feedback is gold right now. And sure, curious about test synthia - what's the approach?

text_clean: It's funny because ours was the opposite. We spent two years focused on pitching, marketing and management. Two coders and two business people; I'm part of the business half. But our first year was spent on talking to people, marketing and pitching to investors. Eventually, we secured preseed by EOY1. Our second year was the attempt to supercharge tech velocity via hiring contractors and going agro on marketing to "pressure the tech team" to build fast. So by EOY2, we had preseed investors, pitch award medals/certs local and intl, beta testers, active socmed, user contacts, marketing interns, hiring experience, an incubator, domain-specific mentors, etc. but no product... LMAO that founding team mix eventually fell apart, we reorganized, and I've learned how to code since then. Thank God. We're now at 30+ users with a working MVP, having only begun this new venture 6 weeks ago. Life is crazy.

text_clean: Starting without validation is basically buying a lottery ticket. You might hit, but odds are you'll spend months building something nobody actually needs. Most "failed" projects don't fail because of bad code, they fail because they solved a problem people didn't care about. Validation doesn't have to be this huge, formal thing either. Just start talking to the people you think you‚Äôre building for. 5 or 10 honest conversations can save you months of building in the wrong direction. interviewing your market is building. Don't get discouraged. You‚Äôre genuinely one good insight away from a direction that clicks.

AI tools used: Claude for pair programming, helped me move way faster than I could alone. I'm not pretending I'm a 10x dev - I'm a guy who learned to build by building. Business model: Monthly subscriptions ($9-39/mo). Launched today, zero customers so far, figuring it out in public. Where I'm launching: You're looking at it - Reddit, LinkedIn, that's it. text_clean: 1- You already have 30 users, that's a lot. Give them features that nudge them to share their experiences in the app on other social media. The ideal marketing tactic is sharing content. Find subs where you can share your concert reviews (and photos, etc.) and that of your users. Find subs where you can engage with your target audience in a way that serves your product. A question like "How do you make sure you don't forget your concert experiences?" is something you could often ask. The goal of these interactions should be to leave a link to your app. 2- Ask your users and listen to the people you engage with (see previous step). Growth will start from them, not from ideas you have. First you listen, then you think about growth tactics. 3- Maybe, if I were in your milieu.

text_clean: If more than 20% of your LTD users are still using your product regularly, that's a good sign. Don't treat them as a headache. Treat them as an opportunity. Talk to them often, not just when they open support tickets. Make them feel like they can reach out to you directly before leaving a bad review. Use them as beta testers when you ship new features. Get their feedback first, then roll out to everyone else. They're already invested in your product. Use that to your advantage.

text_clean: The burnout thing is real. What worked for me was flipping the mindset - instead of trying to reach lots of people, I went deep with like 5-10 potential users. Find people who have the problem you're solving and ask if you can build it with them. Not "try my product" but "I'm building something in this space, would love your input." Most will say no but the ones who say yes become invested. Those first design partners are gold. They'll tell you what's broken before you waste months building the wrong thing. And when it's ready, they're already half-sold because they shaped it. Way less time than cold outreach, and you're actually learning while you go.

text_clean: Every feature request is potentially an opportunity to convert them to a paying tier. Lifetime access is only for the feature set they bought. Develop the new feature on a pay tier and convert them to paying customers. Also they value support, so limit the support requests that they can make in the lifetime tier and upsell them to a higher support tier with more support.

text_clean: From my experience, the mansion problem hits every technical team the first time around. It feels safer to hide in ‚Äúbuilding‚Äù because the work is clear. It was the uncomfortable conversations where someone told me the thing I built was not what they needed. What stood out in your post is how early the gut signals were there. The empty market, the lack of pull, the features drifting away from real demand. Those signals are easy to ignore when you have good tech and momentum. They get louder later, usually when you are already exhausted. You wrote a clean post-mortem. That alone puts you in a better spot for the next round. The people who can look at their own mistakes with that level of clarity are the ones who eventually get a win.

text_clean: Self funding is a dangerous game. I can self fund but I usually don‚Äôt because I want external validation to make sure I am not being stupid. But I‚Äôm most of what you mention about incubators and similar types of things is negotiable. They any act like it‚Äôs not but they want to back successful things so if you are self funding that‚Äôs a reasonable proof point and while you didn‚Äôt say it might imply you have achieved some degree of success already which is another strong proof point. So I‚Äôd try to negotiate. Be very selective must tier 2 or lower accelerator/incubators are sort of hit or miss. And mostly miss. So do a lot of research and make sure you have a plan for how to extract value from it that exceeds what you are giving up.

text_clean: What your friends and family think don't really matter, unless you plan on having them be your source of income. You are going about this backwards. Here is what I would do: You start with a problem and an idea of who has this problem. You talk to these people about the problem to learn as much nuance about the problem as possible. You never mention your idea to them at all. After you have hit diminishing returns on the learning, then you come up with your idea for a solution. You pitch this solution to new people. I would ask them what is the biggest reason this solution would NOT work for them. After you have refined this solution to the point where they ask you about price or about when they can start using it, then you move on to testing the pricing with them. Then you get a handful of people agree to buy it, NOW you build it.

text_clean: Congrats on what you've achieved! Get working capital from your clients in exchange for a discount. There's no need to put your own money down. Partner with a firm to help figure things out. Ideally, you want them one-hundred percent aligned with your vision. Partnering on equity basis for long-term relationship. Realistically, it's probably easier to pay a supplier, rather than seek a partner. Get further validation. Learn a lot. Good luck!
